name: 柯萊恩
objective:
本課程旨在發展學生獨立規劃及從事研究的能力，學生可在指導老師的指導下，依個別的需求選擇研究的方向，訂定題目，並獨立完成研究計畫，撰寫報告。
專題研究範圍含：
實驗研究
量調查研究或質調查研究
個案研究
回溯研究
文化比較研究
理論闡述研究
Each of you working with me over the next year has a unique project—in terms of its topic (each student’s is wildly dissimilar to that of any other student), but also in terms of the methodology you will employ, and the sorts of primary and secondary sources that you will need to unearth.  My job will be to guide you in a way that will enable your project to take shape effectively.  Do not think of your goal as the regurgitation of material that has already been commented upon.  Look at the project as a chance to explore the unknown.  You will find your project can take shape in unexpected ways if you will only let it, but you must make the time to do the work to enable this higher level of scholarship to emerge.
To make full use of what I can offer it is important that you meet with me in my office so we can discuss your progress.  At a bare minimum, I would like you to meet with me at least three times during each semester; for each of these meetings you must prepare, in writing, the logical next step of your project.  I list some suggestions below, but it is possible that your project may have other natural benchmarks.  I purposely do not maintain definite due dates (except, of course, for the final draft of your paper).  Since I have 8-10 special project students, the last thing I want is for every student to hand in her or his paper on the same day.  If that were to happen, because of such a strenuous demand made upon my time, I would not be able to help anybody very much.  So you need to work with me to help me help you.  Take the responsibility to set your own reasonable and effective goals for your project—indeed that is part of what you are learning to do in this class.
schedule:
SEMESTER ONE:
First one-third:  Articulate the intent, scope and methodology of your project.  What are you trying to find out?  Why?  Establish a regular working schedule and write up a schedule of your own benchmarks.
Second one-third:  Review available secondary sources and write response to or evaluation of each one; locate primary sources.  Establish a viable research question.
Third one-third:  Begin working with (reading and writing about) primary sources.
SEMESTER TWO:
First one-third:  Continue writing about primary sources with a view toward establishing a unique, academically interesting thesis idea.  Put everything you’ve written together into one loose bundle contained on a single word file.
Second one-third:  Prepare rough draft of complete paper (including abstract, table of contents, illustrations [if any], bibliography and complete MLA citations), due (at the very latest) by November 1.
Third one-third:  Prepare final draft, due (at the very latest) by December 31.  Prepare power-point presentation.
